raw_text:
MP's shock at long lost daughter
 
 Labour MP Stephen Pound has told of his shock and his joy on learning he fathered a daughter when he was "out of control" during the "wild" 1960s.
 
 Lucy, 36, tracked down Mr Pound after her birth mother told her he was known as "Precious" at school. Despite being told he was a "nutter who died at sea" she found a reference to Mr Pound on Friends Reunited. Lucy's mother kept her pregnancy secret and had her adopted at four weeks. Mr Pound found out about it last year. That happened when Lucy wrote to his Parliamentary office saying she believed he was her father.
 
 Mr Pound, who is now married with two other teenage children, said: "I was a nutter and I was a sailor but I wasn't dead." He said his first reaction was to wonder if he was victim of a "set-up" but he then realised all the dates fitted. "It was a pretty horrible thing with a pretty happy ending. I felt guilt in the marrow of my bones," said the Ealing North MP. "I don't blame Lucy's mother. I was pretty much out of control. I was 18 when she was conceived. It was a different time - it was pretty wild."
 
 Mr Pound says he rang Lucy as soon as he got her letter, they met up and have been in contact ever since. Describing that first meeting at London's King Cross station, he said: "The earth went from under my feet ... We were walking across the Euston Road and I took her arm to take her across and there was an immediate connection. "We were finishing each other sentences." Lucy, who was adopted by a family from Essex, wants to remain anonymous for the sake of her adoptive father and her children. Mr Pound said his wife Maggie had been fully supportive and their two children Emily, 16, and Pelham, 14 were pleased to have an older sister.
llama3.2:1b: Labour MP Stephen Pound was shocked to learn he fathered a daughter named Lucy when he was out of control during the 1960s. He had kept her adoption secret for four years. The discovery happened after he found out about Lucy's birth mother and began contacting her, resulting in an instant connection with his granddaughter at King Cross station.
llama3.2:3b: Labour MP Stephen Pound found out he was the father of a daughter Lucy, 36, when she contacted him after tracing him on Friends Reunited. He was 18 at the time of her conception and was "out of control" during the 1960s. He initially thought it was a setup but later confirmed the dates matched. They met up in London's King Cross station and had an immediate connection, with Pound saying his wife and children were supportive and happy for Lucy to become their sister.
gemma2:2b: Stephen Pound, a Labour MP, learned he fathered a daughter in the 1960s when he was "out of control". Lucy, his daughter, tracked him down after her birth mother revealed he was known as "Precious" at school.  Lucy's adoptive family kept her pregnancy secret and she was adopted at four weeks. Mr Pound learned about her existence last year, leading to a reconciliation with his daughter.  They met in London, where an immediate connection developed. Lucy, who has chosen to remain anonymous, wants to protect the well-being of her adoptive father and children. Her birth father's wife is supportive. Their two other children are pleased to have a new sister.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Stephen Pound, MP for Ealing North, was shocked by the birth of a child who he believed to be his daughter Lucy when she was just 3 weeks old. He had never formally informed his wife Maggie that Lucy was a girl. When he learned about it in the early years of their marriage, he felt guilty and wondered if Lucy's mother was setting him up on purpose. He found the story interesting and decided to tell Lucy that he was her father at a friend's reunion. The couple later wrote to his Parliamentary office and were informed about their daughter Lucy, who is now an 18-year-old girl with two adopted parents.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Labour MP Stephen Pound discovered he was a biological father in his 20s after meeting his long-lost daughter at age 36 on the eve of her seventh birthday. Lucy, now 36, tracked him down through Friends Reunited, despite being raised by an Essex family as someone named "Precious." Mr. Pound initially doubted his identity due to a childhood reference and subsequent experiences in the 'wild' 1960s, but later confirmed it was true after writing Lucy's letter with her adoptive father knowing nothing about their relationship. The couple has been in contact since then; Lucy wants to remain anonymous for privacy reasons.
qwen2.5:3b: Labour MP Stephen Pound revealed his shock and joy upon learning he is a long-lost daughter's biological father from the 'wild' 1960s. His daughter Lucy, now 36, discovered him through Friends Reunited after finding a reference to him at school, where she was known as "Precious." Despite being told Pound was dead and a "nutter," Lucy's mother kept her pregnancy secret and had her adopted shortly after birth. Pound, who is married with two children of his own, confirmed the dates matched their memories. He initially wondered if he was set up but later realized all details aligned. After confirming Lucy's identity via correspondence, they met at King Cross station where an immediate connection formed. While the couple has been in contact since, Lucy prefers to remain anonymous for her adoptive father and his children's sake. Pound's wife Maggie is supportive, and their two children are pleased about having a new sister.

granite3.1-dense:2b:
Labour MP Stephen Pound, now 63, was shocked to discover he fathered a daughter during the 1960s when he was "out of control" and described as a "nutter." Lucy, 36, learned about her biological father from her birth mother's story that Mr Pound was known as "Precious" at school. Despite being told he had died at sea, she found a reference to him on Friends Reunited. Lucy's mother kept her pregnancy secret and had her adopted at four weeks. Last year, Mr Pound learned of Lucy's identity through a letter from her Parliamentary office. Upon receiving the news, he felt initial guilt and wondered if it was a set-up. However, he soon realized the details matched his wild 1960s lifestyle.

Mr Pound, married with two other teenage children, met Lucy at King Cross station after she wrote to his office. They immediately connected, and their first meeting was marked by a strong bond. Lucy, who now lives anonymously for her adoptive father's sake and her own children's, expressed no regrets about seeking her biological father. Mr Pound's wife Maggie supported the reunion, and their two children, Emily (16) and Pelham (14), were happy to have an older sister.
